oldest_reference_title: Basel II Comprehensive version part 2: The First Pillar – Minimum Capital Requirements
citation_claim: Advocates a change in the accounting standards towards an expected loss (EL) approach (usually, EL amount := LGD*PD*EAD).[38]
citation_accuracy_assessment: partially accurate — The referenced Basel II document (p. 86) defines the expected loss formula EL = LGD×PD×EAD, which supports the mathematical notation in the claim. However, the source is a Basel II document being cited in the context of Basel III's advocacy for an EL-based accounting approach, making it a supporting definitional reference rather than a direct Basel III source.

oldest_reference_title: Théorie de la Spéculation [Theory of Speculation]
citation_claim: Louis Bachelier's thesis[3] in 1900 was the earliest publication to apply Brownian motion to derivative pricing, though his work had little impact for many years and included important limitations for its application to modern markets.
citation_accuracy_assessment: accurate — The reference is Bachelier's actual 1900 doctoral thesis, which is universally recognized as the first work to apply Brownian motion (random walk) to financial derivative pricing. Historical consensus confirms that: (1) it was indeed the earliest such publication, predating Einstein's 1905 paper on Brownian motion; (2) it had little impact for decades until rediscovered by Paul Samuelson in the late 1950s; and (3) it included limitations (e.g., allowed negative asset prices) that restrict its direct applicability to modern markets. The reference directly and accurately supports all aspects of the claim.

oldest_reference_title: Toward the therapeutic editing of mutated RNA sequences
oldest_reference_authors: Woolf TM, Chase JM, Stinchcomb DT
citation_claim: Directing edits to correct mutated sequences was first proposed and demonstrated in 1995. This initial work used synthetic RNA antisense oligonucleotides complementary to a pre-mature stop codon mutation in a dystrophin sequence to activate A-to-I editing of the stop codon to a read through codon in a model xenopus cell system.

oldest_reference_title: Note on census-taking in Monte Carlo calculations
citation_claim: The origins of Quantum Monte Carlo methods are often attributed to Enrico Fermi and Robert Richtmyer who developed in 1948 a mean-field particle interpretation of neutron-chain reactions.[37]
citation_accuracy_assessment: accurate — The reference is Fermi and Richtmyer's 1948 Los Alamos report on Monte Carlo calculations (census-taking methods for neutron-chain reactions), which directly supports the article's claim that they developed a mean-field particle interpretation of neutron-chain reactions in 1948.

citation_claim: The eigenvalue problem behind PageRank's algorithm was independently rediscovered and reused in many scoring problems. In 1895, Edmund Landau suggested using it for determining the winner of a chess tournament.
citation_accuracy_assessment: accurate — The reference is an 1895 paper by Edmund Landau in Deutsches Wochenschach proposing the use of eigenvalue-based ranking for chess tournament results, which directly and correctly supports the article's claim that Landau applied this concept to determining chess tournament winners in 1895.

citation_claim: Clifford Cocks, an English mathematician working for the British intelligence agency Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ), described a similar system in an internal document in 1973. However, given the relatively expensive computers needed to implement it at the time, it was considered to be mostly a curiosity and, as far as is publicly known, was never deployed. His ideas and concepts were not revealed until 1997 due to its top-secret classification.

oldest_reference_title: 18 U.S. Code § 1350 - Failure of corporate officers to certify financial reports | U.S. Code | US Law | LII / Legal Information Institute
oldest_reference_authors: No named authors (U.S. federal statute published on LII / Legal Information Institute)
citation_claim: (2) willfully certifies any statement as set forth in subsections (a) and (b) of this section knowing that the periodic report accompanying the statement does not comport with all the requirements set forth in this section shall be fined not more than $5,000,000, or imprisoned not more than 20 years, or both.[68]
citation_accuracy_assessment: accurate — The reference links directly to 18 U.S.C. § 1350 on the LII website, which is the exact statutory provision being quoted in the article. The article reproduces the legal text of the law verbatim, and the reference correctly points to that authoritative source.

oldest_reference_title: The correlation theory of brain function
citation_claim: One of its two networks has "fast weights" or "dynamic links" (1981).[17][18][19] — in context: "The linearly scaling fast weight controller (1992) learns to compute a weight matrix for further processing depending on the input. One of its two networks has 'fast weights' or 'dynamic links' (1981)."
citation_accuracy_assessment: accurate — The von der Malsburg (1981) paper on the correlation theory of brain function introduced the concept of 'dynamic links' (dynamic connections) in neural networks, which is exactly what the Wikipedia article cites it for. The reference correctly supports the claim about the historical origin of the 'dynamic links' concept used in the fast weight controller architecture.
